member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateAccess operation. Used by administrators to choose which groups in the directory should have access to upload and download files over the enabled protocols using Amazon Web Services Transfer Family. For example, a Microsoft Active Directory might contain 50,000 users, but only a small fraction might need the ability to transfer files to the server. An administrator can use CreateAccess to limit the access to the correct set of users who need this ability.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest.ExternalId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExternalId.
A unique identifier that is required to identify specific groups within your directory. The users of the group that you associate have access to your Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS resources over the enabled protocols using Amazon Web Services Transfer Family. If you know the group name, you can view the SID values by running the following command using Windows PowerShell.
Get-ADGroup -Filter {samAccountName -like "YourGroupName*"} -Properties * | Select SamAccountName,ObjectSid
In that command, replace YourGroupName with the name of your Active Directory group.
The regex used to validate this parameter is a string of characters consisting of uppercase and lowercase alphanumeric characters with no spaces. You can also include underscores or any of the following characters: =,.@:/-

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest.HomeDirectory
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectory.
The landing directory (folder) for a user when they log in to the server using the client.
A HomeDirectory example is /bucket_name/home/mydirectory.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest.HomeDirectoryMappings
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryMappings.
Logical directory mappings that specify what Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS paths and keys should be visible to your user and how you want to make them visible. You must specify the Entry and Target pair, where Entry shows how the path is made visible and Target is the actual Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS path. If you only specify a target, it is displayed as is. You also must ensure that your Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) role provides access to paths in Target. This value can only be set when HomeDirectoryType is set to LOGICAL.
The following is an Entry and Target pair example.
[ { "Entry": "/directory1", "Target": "/bucket_name/home/mydirectory" } ]
In most cases, you can use this value instead of the session policy to lock down your user to the designated home directory ("chroot"). To do this, you can set Entry to / and set Target to the HomeDirectory parameter value.
The following is an Entry and Target pair example for chroot.
[ { "Entry:": "/", "Target": "/bucket_name/home/mydirectory" } ]
If the target of a logical directory entry does not exist in Amazon S3 or EFS, the entry is ignored. As a workaround, you can use the Amazon S3 API or EFS API to create 0 byte objects as place holders for your directory. If using the CLI, use the s3api or efsapi call instead of s3 or efs so you can use the put-object operation. For example, you use the following: aws s3api put-object --bucket bucketname --key path/to/folder/. Make sure that the end of the key name ends in a / for it to be considered a folder.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest.HomeDirectoryType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryType.
The type of landing directory (folder) you want your users' home directory to be when they log into the server. If you set it to PATH, the user will see the absolute Amazon S3 bucket or EFS paths as is in their file transfer protocol clients. If you set it LOGICAL, you need to provide mappings in the HomeDirectoryMappings for how you want to make Amazon S3 or EFS paths visible to your users.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest.Policy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Policy.
A session policy for your user so that you can use the same IAM role across multiple users. This policy scopes down user access to portions of their Amazon S3 bucket. Variables that you can use inside this policy include ${Transfer:UserName}, ${Transfer:HomeDirectory}, and ${Transfer:HomeBucket}.
This only applies when the domain of ServerId is S3. EFS does not use session policies.
For session policies, Amazon Web Services Transfer Family stores the policy as a JSON blob, instead of the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the policy. You save the policy as a JSON blob and pass it in the Policy argument.
For an example of a session policy, see Example session policy.
For more information, see AssumeRole in the Amazon Web Services Security Token Service API Reference.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest.PosixProfile
member.summary: Gets and sets the property PosixProfile.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest.Role
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Role.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that controls your users' access to your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The policies attached to this role determine the level of access that you want to provide your users when transferring files into and out of your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The IAM role should also contain a trust relationship that allows the server to access your resources when servicing your users' transfer requests.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessRequest.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server instance. This is the specific server that you added your user to.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateAccess operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessResponse.ExternalId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExternalId.
The external ID of the group whose users have access to your Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS resources over the enabled protocols using Amazon Web Services Transfer Family.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateAccessResponse.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
The ID of the server that the user is attached to.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateServer operation. Instantiates an auto-scaling virtual server based on the selected file transfer protocol in Amazon Web Services. When you make updates to your file transfer protocol-enabled server or when you work with users, use the service-generated ServerId property that is assigned to the newly created server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.Certificate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Certificate.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon Web Services Certificate Manager (ACM) certificate. Required when Protocols is set to FTPS.
To request a new public certificate, see Request a public certificate in the Amazon Web Services Certificate Manager User Guide.
To import an existing certificate into ACM, see Importing certificates into ACM in the Amazon Web Services Certificate Manager User Guide.
To request a private certificate to use FTPS through private IP addresses, see Request a private certificate in the Amazon Web Services Certificate Manager User Guide.
Certificates with the following cryptographic algorithms and key sizes are supported:
2048-bit RSA (RSA_2048)
4096-bit RSA (RSA_4096)
Elliptic Prime Curve 256 bit (EC_prime256v1)
Elliptic Prime Curve 384 bit (EC_secp384r1)
Elliptic Prime Curve 521 bit (EC_secp521r1)
The certificate must be a valid SSL/TLS X.509 version 3 certificate with FQDN or IP address specified and information about the issuer.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.Domain
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Domain.
The domain of the storage system that is used for file transfers. There are two domains available: Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) and Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS). The default value is S3.
After the server is created, the domain cannot be changed.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.EndpointDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EndpointDetails.
The virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint settings that are configured for your server. When you host your endpoint within your VPC, you can make it accessible only to resources within your VPC, or you can attach Elastic IP addresses and make it accessible to clients over the internet. Your VPC's default security groups are automatically assigned to your endpoint.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.EndpointType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EndpointType.
The type of endpoint that you want your server to use. You can choose to make your server's endpoint publicly accessible (PUBLIC) or host it inside your VPC. With an endpoint that is hosted in a VPC, you can restrict access to your server and resources only within your VPC or choose to make it internet facing by attaching Elastic IP addresses directly to it.
After May 19, 2021, you won't be able to create a server using EndpointType=VPC_ENDPOINT in your Amazon Web Services account if your account hasn't already done so before May 19, 2021. If you have already created servers with EndpointType=VPC_ENDPOINT in your Amazon Web Services account on or before May 19, 2021, you will not be affected. After this date, use EndpointType=VPC.
For more information, see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/transfer/latest/userguide/create-server-in-vpc.html#deprecate-vpc-endpoint.
It is recommended that you use VPC as the EndpointType. With this endpoint type, you have the option to directly associate up to three Elastic IPv4 addresses (BYO IP included) with your server's endpoint and use VPC security groups to restrict traffic by the client's public IP address. This is not possible with EndpointType set to VPC_ENDPOINT.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.HostKey
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HostKey.
The RSA private key as generated by the ssh-keygen -N "" -m PEM -f my-new-server-key command.
If you aren't planning to migrate existing users from an existing SFTP-enabled server to a new server, don't update the host key. Accidentally changing a server's host key can be disruptive.
For more information, see Change the host key for your SFTP-enabled server in the Amazon Web Services Transfer Family User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.IdentityProviderDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IdentityProviderDetails.
Required when IdentityProviderType is set to AWS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE or API_GATEWAY. Accepts an array containing all of the information required to use a directory in AWS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE or invoke a customer-supplied authentication API, including the API Gateway URL. Not required when IdentityProviderType is set to SERVICE_MANAGED.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.IdentityProviderType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IdentityProviderType.
Specifies the mode of authentication for a server. The default value is SERVICE_MANAGED, which allows you to store and access user credentials within the Amazon Web Services Transfer Family service.
Use AWS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE to provide access to Active Directory groups in Amazon Web Services Managed Active Directory or Microsoft Active Directory in your on-premises environment or in Amazon Web Services using AD Connectors. This option also requires you to provide a Directory ID using the IdentityProviderDetails parameter.
Use the API_GATEWAY value to integrate with an identity provider of your choosing. The API_GATEWAY setting requires you to provide an API Gateway endpoint URL to call for authentication using the IdentityProviderDetails parameter.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.LoggingRole
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LoggingRole.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that allows a server to turn on Amazon CloudWatch logging for Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS events. When set, user activity can be viewed in your CloudWatch logs.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.Protocols
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Protocols.
Specifies the file transfer protocol or protocols over which your file transfer protocol client can connect to your server's endpoint. The available protocols are:
SFTP (Secure Shell (SSH) File Transfer Protocol): File transfer over SSH
FTPS (File Transfer Protocol Secure): File transfer with TLS encryption
FTP (File Transfer Protocol): Unencrypted file transfer
If you select FTPS, you must choose a certificate stored in Amazon Web Services Certificate Manager (ACM) which is used to identify your server when clients connect to it over FTPS.
If Protocol includes either FTP or FTPS, then the EndpointType must be VPC and the IdentityProviderType must be AWS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE or API_GATEWAY.
If Protocol includes FTP, then AddressAllocationIds cannot be associated.
If Protocol is set only to SFTP, the EndpointType can be set to PUBLIC and the IdentityProviderType can be set to SERVICE_MANAGED.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.SecurityPolicyName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SecurityPolicyName.
Specifies the name of the security policy that is attached to the server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Key-value pairs that can be used to group and search for servers.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerRequest.WorkflowDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkflowDetails.
Specifies the workflow ID for the workflow to assign and the execution role used for executing the workflow.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateServer operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateServerResponse.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
The service-assigned ID of the server that is created.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateUser operation. Creates a user and associates them with an existing file transfer protocol-enabled server. You can only create and associate users with servers that have the IdentityProviderType set to SERVICE_MANAGED. Using parameters for CreateUser, you can specify the user name, set the home directory, store the user's public key, and assign the user's Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) role. You can also optionally add a session policy, and assign metadata with tags that can be used to group and search for users.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.HomeDirectory
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectory.
The landing directory (folder) for a user when they log in to the server using the client.
A HomeDirectory example is /bucket_name/home/mydirectory.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.HomeDirectoryMappings
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryMappings.
Logical directory mappings that specify what Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS paths and keys should be visible to your user and how you want to make them visible. You must specify the Entry and Target pair, where Entry shows how the path is made visible and Target is the actual Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS path. If you only specify a target, it is displayed as is. You also must ensure that your Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) role provides access to paths in Target. This value can only be set when HomeDirectoryType is set to LOGICAL.
The following is an Entry and Target pair example.
[ { "Entry": "/directory1", "Target": "/bucket_name/home/mydirectory" } ]
In most cases, you can use this value instead of the session policy to lock your user down to the designated home directory ("chroot"). To do this, you can set Entry to / and set Target to the HomeDirectory parameter value.
The following is an Entry and Target pair example for chroot.
[ { "Entry:": "/", "Target": "/bucket_name/home/mydirectory" } ]
If the target of a logical directory entry does not exist in Amazon S3 or EFS, the entry is ignored. As a workaround, you can use the Amazon S3 API or EFS API to create 0 byte objects as place holders for your directory. If using the CLI, use the s3api or efsapi call instead of s3 or efs so you can use the put-object operation. For example, you use the following: aws s3api put-object --bucket bucketname --key path/to/folder/. Make sure that the end of the key name ends in a / for it to be considered a folder.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.HomeDirectoryType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryType.
The type of landing directory (folder) you want your users' home directory to be when they log into the server. If you set it to PATH, the user will see the absolute Amazon S3 bucket or EFS paths as is in their file transfer protocol clients. If you set it LOGICAL, you need to provide mappings in the HomeDirectoryMappings for how you want to make Amazon S3 or EFS paths visible to your users.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.Policy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Policy.
A session policy for your user so that you can use the same IAM role across multiple users. This policy scopes down user access to portions of their Amazon S3 bucket. Variables that you can use inside this policy include ${Transfer:UserName}, ${Transfer:HomeDirectory}, and ${Transfer:HomeBucket}.
This only applies when the domain of ServerId is S3. EFS does not use session policies.
For session policies, Amazon Web Services Transfer Family stores the policy as a JSON blob, instead of the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the policy. You save the policy as a JSON blob and pass it in the Policy argument.
For an example of a session policy, see Example session policy.
For more information, see AssumeRole in the Amazon Web Services Security Token Service API Reference.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.PosixProfile
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PosixProfile.
Specifies the full POSIX identity, including user ID (Uid), group ID (Gid), and any secondary groups IDs (SecondaryGids), that controls your users' access to your Amazon EFS file systems. The POSIX permissions that are set on files and directories in Amazon EFS determine the level of access your users get when transferring files into and out of your Amazon EFS file systems.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.Role
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Role.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that controls your users' access to your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The policies attached to this role determine the level of access that you want to provide your users when transferring files into and out of your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The IAM role should also contain a trust relationship that allows the server to access your resources when servicing your users' transfer requests.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server instance. This is the specific server that you added your user to.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.SshPublicKeyBody
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SshPublicKeyBody.
The public portion of the Secure Shell (SSH) key used to authenticate the user to the server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Key-value pairs that can be used to group and search for users. Tags are metadata attached to users for any purpose.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserRequest.UserName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UserName.
A unique string that identifies a user and is associated with a ServerId. This user name must be a minimum of 3 and a maximum of 100 characters long. The following are valid characters: a-z, A-Z, 0-9, underscore '_', hyphen '-', period '.', and at sign '@'. The user name can't start with a hyphen, period, or at sign.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateUser operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserResponse.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
The ID of the server that the user is attached to.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateUserResponse.UserName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UserName.
A unique string that identifies a user account associated with a server.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateWorkflowRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateWorkflow operation. Allows you to create a workflow with specified steps and step details the workflow invokes after file transfer completes. After creating a workflow, you can associate the workflow created with any transfer servers by specifying the workflow-details field in CreateServer and UpdateServer operations.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateWorkflowRequest.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
A textual description for the workflow.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateWorkflowRequest.OnExceptionSteps
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OnExceptionSteps.
Specifies the steps (actions) to take if errors are encountered during execution of the workflow.
For custom steps, the lambda function needs to send FAILURE to the call back API to kick off the exception steps. Additionally, if the lambda does not send SUCCESS before it times out, the exception steps are executed.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateWorkflowRequest.Steps
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Steps.
Specifies the details for the steps that are in the specified workflow.
The TYPE specifies which of the following actions is being taken for this step.
Copy: copy the file to another location
Custom: custom step with a lambda target
Delete: delete the file
Tag: add a tag to the file
Currently, copying and tagging are supported only on S3.
For file location, you specify either the S3 bucket and key, or the EFS filesystem ID and path.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateWorkflowRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Key-value pairs that can be used to group and search for workflows. Tags are metadata attached to workflows for any purpose.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateWorkflowResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateWorkflow operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CreateWorkflowResponse.WorkflowId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkflowId.
A unique identifier for the workflow.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CustomStepDetails
member.summary: Each step type has its own StepDetails structure.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CustomStepDetails.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the step, used as an identifier.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CustomStepDetails.Target
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Target.
The ARN for the lambda function that is being called.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.CustomStepDetails.TimeoutSeconds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TimeoutSeconds.
Timeout, in seconds, for the step.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DeleteAccessRequest

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DeleteAccessRequest.ExternalId

A unique identifier that is required to identify specific groups within your directory. The users of the group that you associate have access to your Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS resources over the enabled protocols using Amazon Web Services Transfer Family. If you know the group name, you can view the SID values by running the following command using Windows PowerShell.
Get-ADGroup -Filter {samAccountName -like "YourGroupName*"} -Properties * | Select SamAccountName,ObjectSid
In that command, replace YourGroupName with the name of your Active Directory group.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DeleteAccessRequest.ServerId

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribeAccessRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DescribeAccess operation. Describes the access that is assigned to the specific file transfer protocol-enabled server, as identified by its ServerId property and its ExternalID.
The response from this call returns the properties of the access that is associated with the ServerId value that was specified.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribeAccessRequest.ExternalId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExternalId.
A unique identifier that is required to identify specific groups within your directory. The users of the group that you associate have access to your Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS resources over the enabled protocols using Amazon Web Services Transfer Family. If you know the group name, you can view the SID values by running the following command using Windows PowerShell.
Get-ADGroup -Filter {samAccountName -like "YourGroupName*"} -Properties * | Select SamAccountName,ObjectSid
In that command, replace YourGroupName with the name of your Active Directory group.
The regex used to validate this parameter is a string of characters consisting of uppercase and lowercase alphanumeric characters with no spaces. You can also include underscores or any of the following characters: =,.@:/-

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribeAccessRequest.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server that has this access assigned.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribeAccessResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DescribeAccess operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribeAccessResponse.Access
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Access.
The external ID of the server that the access is attached to.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribeAccessResponse.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server that has this access assigned.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedAccess
member.summary: Describes the properties of the access that was specified.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedAccess.ExternalId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExternalId.
A unique identifier that is required to identify specific groups within your directory. The users of the group that you associate have access to your Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS resources over the enabled protocols using Amazon Web Services Transfer Family. If you know the group name, you can view the SID values by running the following command using Windows PowerShell.
Get-ADGroup -Filter {samAccountName -like "YourGroupName*"} -Properties * | Select SamAccountName,ObjectSid
In that command, replace YourGroupName with the name of your Active Directory group.
The regex used to validate this parameter is a string of characters consisting of uppercase and lowercase alphanumeric characters with no spaces. You can also include underscores or any of the following characters: =,.@:/-

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedAccess.HomeDirectory
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectory.
The landing directory (folder) for a user when they log in to the server using the client.
A HomeDirectory example is /bucket_name/home/mydirectory.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedAccess.HomeDirectoryMappings
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryMappings.
Logical directory mappings that specify what Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS paths and keys should be visible to your user and how you want to make them visible. You must specify the Entry and Target pair, where Entry shows how the path is made visible and Target is the actual Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS path. If you only specify a target, it is displayed as is. You also must ensure that your Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) role provides access to paths in Target. This value can only be set when HomeDirectoryType is set to LOGICAL.
In most cases, you can use this value instead of the session policy to lock down the associated access to the designated home directory ("chroot"). To do this, you can set Entry to '/' and set Target to the HomeDirectory parameter value.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedAccess.HomeDirectoryType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryType.
The type of landing directory (folder) you want your users' home directory to be when they log into the server. If you set it to PATH, the user will see the absolute Amazon S3 bucket or EFS paths as is in their file transfer protocol clients. If you set it LOGICAL, you need to provide mappings in the HomeDirectoryMappings for how you want to make Amazon S3 or EFS paths visible to your users.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedAccess.Policy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Policy.
A session policy for your user so that you can use the same IAM role across multiple users. This policy scopes down user access to portions of their Amazon S3 bucket. Variables that you can use inside this policy include ${Transfer:UserName}, ${Transfer:HomeDirectory}, and ${Transfer:HomeBucket}.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedAccess.PosixProfile
member.summary: Gets and sets the property PosixProfile.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedAccess.Role
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Role.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that controls your users' access to your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The policies attached to this role determine the level of access that you want to provide your users when transferring files into and out of your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The IAM role should also contain a trust relationship that allows the server to access your resources when servicing your users' transfer requests.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution
member.summary: The details for an execution object.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution.ExecutionId
member.summary:

A unique identifier for the execution of a workflow.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution.ExecutionRole
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionRole.
The IAM role associated with the execution.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution.InitialFileLocation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InitialFileLocation.
A structure that describes the Amazon S3 or EFS file location. This is the file location when the execution begins: if the file is being copied, this is the initial (as opposed to destination) file location.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution.LoggingConfiguration
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LoggingConfiguration.
The IAM logging role associated with the execution.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution.PosixProfile
member.summary: Gets and sets the property PosixProfile.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution.Results
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Results.
A structure that describes the execution results. This includes a list of the steps along with the details of each step, error type and message (if any), and the OnExceptionSteps structure.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution.ServiceMetadata
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServiceMetadata.
A container object for the session details associated with a workflow.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedExecution.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
The status is one of the execution. Can be in progress, completed, exception encountered, or handling the exception.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedSecurityPolicy
member.summary: Describes the properties of a security policy that was specified. For more information about security policies, see Working with security policies.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedSecurityPolicy.Fips
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Fips.
Specifies whether this policy enables Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS).

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedSecurityPolicy.SecurityPolicyName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SecurityPolicyName.
Specifies the name of the security policy that is attached to the server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedSecurityPolicy.SshCiphers
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SshCiphers.
Specifies the enabled Secure Shell (SSH) cipher encryption algorithms in the security policy that is attached to the server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedSecurityPolicy.SshKexs
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SshKexs.
Specifies the enabled SSH key exchange (KEX) encryption algorithms in the security policy that is attached to the server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedSecurityPolicy.SshMacs
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SshMacs.
Specifies the enabled SSH message authentication code (MAC) encryption algorithms in the security policy that is attached to the server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedSecurityPolicy.TlsCiphers
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TlsCiphers.
Specifies the enabled Transport Layer Security (TLS) cipher encryption algorithms in the security policy that is attached to the server.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer
member.summary: Describes the properties of a file transfer protocol-enabled server that was specified.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.Arn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Arn.
Specifies the unique Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.Certificate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Certificate.
Specifies the ARN of the Amazon Web ServicesCertificate Manager (ACM) certificate. Required when Protocols is set to FTPS.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.Domain
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Domain.
Specifies the domain of the storage system that is used for file transfers.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.EndpointDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EndpointDetails.
The virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint settings that are configured for your server. When you host your endpoint within your VPC, you can make it accessible only to resources within your VPC, or you can attach Elastic IP addresses and make it accessible to clients over the internet. Your VPC's default security groups are automatically assigned to your endpoint.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.EndpointType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EndpointType.
Defines the type of endpoint that your server is connected to. If your server is connected to a VPC endpoint, your server isn't accessible over the public internet.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.HostKeyFingerprint
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HostKeyFingerprint.
Specifies the Base64-encoded SHA256 fingerprint of the server's host key. This value is equivalent to the output of the ssh-keygen -l -f my-new-server-key command.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.IdentityProviderDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IdentityProviderDetails.
Specifies information to call a customer-supplied authentication API. This field is not populated when the IdentityProviderType of a server is AWS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE or SERVICE_MANAGED.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.IdentityProviderType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IdentityProviderType.
Specifies the mode of authentication for a server. The default value is SERVICE_MANAGED, which allows you to store and access user credentials within the Amazon Web Services Transfer Family service.
Use AWS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE to provide access to Active Directory groups in Amazon Web Services Managed Active Directory or Microsoft Active Directory in your on-premises environment or in Amazon Web Services using AD Connectors. This option also requires you to provide a Directory ID using the IdentityProviderDetails parameter.
Use the API_GATEWAY value to integrate with an identity provider of your choosing. The API_GATEWAY setting requires you to provide an API Gateway endpoint URL to call for authentication using the IdentityProviderDetails parameter.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.LoggingRole
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LoggingRole.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that allows a server to turn on Amazon CloudWatch logging for Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS events. When set, user activity can be viewed in your CloudWatch logs.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.ProtocolDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ProtocolDetails.
The protocol settings that are configured for your server.
Use the PassiveIp parameter to indicate passive mode. Enter a single dotted-quad IPv4 address, such as the external IP address of a firewall, router, or load balancer.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.Protocols
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Protocols.
Specifies the file transfer protocol or protocols over which your file transfer protocol client can connect to your server's endpoint. The available protocols are:
SFTP (Secure Shell (SSH) File Transfer Protocol): File transfer over SSH
FTPS (File Transfer Protocol Secure): File transfer with TLS encryption
FTP (File Transfer Protocol): Unencrypted file transfer

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.SecurityPolicyName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SecurityPolicyName.
Specifies the name of the security policy that is attached to the server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
Specifies the unique system-assigned identifier for a server that you instantiate.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.State
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property State.
Specifies the condition of a server for the server that was described. A value of ONLINE indicates that the server can accept jobs and transfer files. A State value of OFFLINE means that the server cannot perform file transfer operations.
The states of STARTING and STOPPING indicate that the server is in an intermediate state, either not fully able to respond, or not fully offline. The values of START_FAILED or STOP_FAILED can indicate an error condition.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Specifies the key-value pairs that you can use to search for and group servers that were assigned to the server that was described.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.UserCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UserCount.
Specifies the number of users that are assigned to a server you specified with the ServerId.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedServer.WorkflowDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkflowDetails.
Specifies the workflow ID for the workflow to assign and the execution role used for executing the workflow.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser
member.summary: Describes the properties of a user that was specified.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.Arn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Arn.
Specifies the unique Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the user that was requested to be described.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.HomeDirectory
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectory.
The landing directory (folder) for a user when they log in to the server using the client.
A HomeDirectory example is /bucket_name/home/mydirectory.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.HomeDirectoryMappings
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryMappings.
Logical directory mappings that specify what Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS paths and keys should be visible to your user and how you want to make them visible. You must specify the Entry and Target pair, where Entry shows how the path is made visible and Target is the actual Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS path. If you only specify a target, it is displayed as is. You also must ensure that your Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) role provides access to paths in Target. This value can only be set when HomeDirectoryType is set to LOGICAL.
In most cases, you can use this value instead of the session policy to lock your user down to the designated home directory ("chroot"). To do this, you can set Entry to '/' and set Target to the HomeDirectory parameter value.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.HomeDirectoryType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryType.
The type of landing directory (folder) you want your users' home directory to be when they log into the server. If you set it to PATH, the user will see the absolute Amazon S3 bucket or EFS paths as is in their file transfer protocol clients. If you set it LOGICAL, you need to provide mappings in the HomeDirectoryMappings for how you want to make Amazon S3 or EFS paths visible to your users.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.Policy
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Policy.
A session policy for your user so that you can use the same IAM role across multiple users. This policy scopes down user access to portions of their Amazon S3 bucket. Variables that you can use inside this policy include ${Transfer:UserName}, ${Transfer:HomeDirectory}, and ${Transfer:HomeBucket}.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.PosixProfile
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PosixProfile.
Specifies the full POSIX identity, including user ID (Uid), group ID (Gid), and any secondary groups IDs (SecondaryGids), that controls your users' access to your Amazon Elastic File System (Amazon EFS) file systems. The POSIX permissions that are set on files and directories in your file system determine the level of access your users get when transferring files into and out of your Amazon EFS file systems.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.Role
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Role.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that controls your users' access to your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The policies attached to this role determine the level of access that you want to provide your users when transferring files into and out of your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The IAM role should also contain a trust relationship that allows the server to access your resources when servicing your users' transfer requests.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.SshPublicKeys
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SshPublicKeys.
Specifies the public key portion of the Secure Shell (SSH) keys stored for the described user.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Specifies the key-value pairs for the user requested. Tag can be used to search for and group users for a variety of purposes.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.DescribedUser.UserName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UserName.
Specifies the name of the user that was requested to be described. User names are used for authentication purposes. This is the string that will be used by your user when they log in to your server.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.EndpointDetails
member.summary:
The virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint settings that are configured for your file transfer protocol-enabled server. With a VPC endpoint, you can restrict access to your server and resources only within your VPC. To control incoming internet traffic, invoke the UpdateServer API and attach an Elastic IP address to your server's endpoint.
After May 19, 2021, you won't be able to create a server using EndpointType=VPC_ENDPOINT in your Amazon Web Servicesaccount if your account hasn't already done so before May 19, 2021. If you have already created servers with EndpointType=VPC_ENDPOINT in your Amazon Web Servicesaccount on or before May 19, 2021, you will not be affected. After this date, use EndpointType=VPC.
For more information, see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/transfer/latest/userguide/create-server-in-vpc.html#deprecate-vpc-endpoint.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.EndpointDetails.AddressAllocationIds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AddressAllocationIds.
A list of address allocation IDs that are required to attach an Elastic IP address to your server's endpoint.
This property can only be set when EndpointType is set to VPC and it is only valid in the UpdateServer API.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.EndpointDetails.SecurityGroupIds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SecurityGroupIds.
A list of security groups IDs that are available to attach to your server's endpoint.
This property can only be set when EndpointType is set to VPC.
You can edit the SecurityGroupIds property in the UpdateServer API only if you are changing the EndpointType from PUBLIC or VPC_ENDPOINT to VPC. To change security groups associated with your server's VPC endpoint after creation, use the Amazon EC2 ModifyVpcEndpoint API.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.EndpointDetails.SubnetIds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SubnetIds.
A list of subnet IDs that are required to host your server endpoint in your VPC.
This property can only be set when EndpointType is set to VPC.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.EndpointDetails.VpcEndpointId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property VpcEndpointId.
The ID of the VPC endpoint.
This property can only be set when EndpointType is set to VPC_ENDPOINT.
For more information, see https://docs.aws.amazon.com/transfer/latest/userguide/create-server-in-vpc.html#deprecate-vpc-endpoint.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.EndpointDetails.VpcId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property VpcId.
The VPC ID of the VPC in which a server's endpoint will be hosted.
This property can only be set when EndpointType is set to VPC.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionError
member.summary: Specifies the error message and type, for an error that occurs during the execution of the workflow.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionError.Message
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Message.
Specifies the descriptive message that corresponds to the ErrorType.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionError.Type
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Type.
Specifies the error type: currently, the only valid value is PERMISSION_DENIED, which occurs if your policy does not contain the correct permissions to complete one or more of the steps in the workflow.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionResults
member.summary: Specifies the steps in the workflow, as well as the steps to execute in case of any errors during workflow execution.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionResults.OnExceptionSteps
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OnExceptionSteps.
Specifies the steps (actions) to take if errors are encountered during execution of the workflow.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionResults.Steps
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Steps.
Specifies the details for the steps that are in the specified workflow.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionStepResult
member.summary: Specifies the following details for the step: error (if any), outputs (if any), and the step type.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionStepResult.Error
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Error.
Specifies the details for an error, if it occurred during execution of the specified workfow step.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionStepResult.Outputs
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Outputs.
The values for the key/value pair applied as a tag to the file. Only applicable if the step type is TAG.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ExecutionStepResult.StepType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StepType.
One of the available step types.
Copy: copy the file to another location
Custom: custom step with a lambda target
Delete: delete the file
Tag: add a tag to the file

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.FileLocation
member.summary: Specifies the Amazon S3 or EFS file details to be used in the step.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.FileLocation.EfsFileLocation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EfsFileLocation.
Specifies the Amazon EFS ID and the path for the file being used.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.FileLocation.S3FileLocation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property S3FileLocation.
Specifies the S3 details for the file being used, such as bucket, Etag, and so forth.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.HomeDirectoryMapEntry
member.summary:
Represents an object that contains entries and targets for HomeDirectoryMappings.
The following is an Entry and Target pair example for chroot.
[ { "Entry:": "/", "Target": "/bucket_name/home/mydirectory" } ]
If the target of a logical directory entry does not exist in Amazon S3 or EFS, the entry is ignored. As a workaround, you can use the Amazon S3 API or EFS API to create 0 byte objects as place holders for your directory. If using the CLI, use the s3api or efsapi call instead of s3 or efs so you can use the put-object operation. For example, you use the following: aws s3api put-object --bucket bucketname --key path/to/folder/. Make sure that the end of the key name ends in a / for it to be considered a folder.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.HomeDirectoryMapEntry.Entry
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Entry.
Represents an entry for HomeDirectoryMappings.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.HomeDirectoryMapEntry.Target
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Target.
Represents the map target that is used in a HomeDirectorymapEntry.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.IdentityProviderDetails
member.summary: Returns information related to the type of user authentication that is in use for a file transfer protocol-enabled server's users. A server can have only one method of authentication.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.IdentityProviderDetails.DirectoryId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DirectoryId.
The identifier of the Amazon Web ServicesDirectory Service directory that you want to stop sharing.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.IdentityProviderDetails.InvocationRole
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InvocationRole.
Provides the type of InvocationRole used to authenticate the user account.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.IdentityProviderDetails.Url
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Url.
Provides the location of the service endpoint used to authenticate users.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ImportSshPublicKeyRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the ImportSshPublicKey operation. Adds a Secure Shell (SSH) public key to a user account identified by a UserName value assigned to the specific file transfer protocol-enabled server, identified by ServerId.
The response returns the UserName value, the ServerId value, and the name of the SshPublicKeyId.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ImportSshPublicKeyRequest.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ImportSshPublicKeyRequest.SshPublicKeyBody
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SshPublicKeyBody.
The public key portion of an SSH key pair.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ImportSshPublicKeyRequest.UserName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UserName.
The name of the user account that is assigned to one or more servers.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ImportSshPublicKeyResponse
member.summary: Identifies the user, the server they belong to, and the identifier of the SSH public key associated with that user. A user can have more than one key on each server that they are associated with.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ImportSshPublicKeyResponse.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ImportSshPublicKeyResponse.SshPublicKeyId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SshPublicKeyId.
The name given to a public key by the system that was imported.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ImportSshPublicKeyResponse.UserName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UserName.
A user name assigned to the ServerID value that you specified.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.InputFileLocation
member.summary: Specifies the location for the file being copied. Only applicable for the Copy type of workflow steps.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.InputFileLocation.EfsFileLocation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EfsFileLocation.
Reserved for future use.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.InputFileLocation.S3FileLocation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property S3FileLocation.
Specifies the details for the S3 file being copied.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListAccessesRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListAccesses operation. Lists the details for all the accesses you have on your server.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListAccessesRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
Specifies the maximum number of access SIDs to return.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListAccessesRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
When you can get additional results from the ListAccesses call, a NextToken parameter is returned in the output. You can then pass in a subsequent command to the NextToken parameter to continue listing additional accesses.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListAccessesRequest.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server that has users assigned to it.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListAccessesResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListAccesses operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListAccessesResponse.Accesses
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Accesses.
Returns the accesses and their properties for the ServerId value that you specify.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListAccessesResponse.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
When you can get additional results from the ListAccesses call, a NextToken parameter is returned in the output. You can then pass in a subsequent command to the NextToken parameter to continue listing additional accesses.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListAccessesResponse.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server that has users assigned to it.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedAccess
member.summary: Lists the properties for one or more specified associated accesses.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedAccess.ExternalId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExternalId.
A unique identifier that is required to identify specific groups within your directory. The users of the group that you associate have access to your Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS resources over the enabled protocols using Amazon Web Services Transfer Family. If you know the group name, you can view the SID values by running the following command using Windows PowerShell.
Get-ADGroup -Filter {samAccountName -like "YourGroupName*"} -Properties * | Select SamAccountName,ObjectSid
In that command, replace YourGroupName with the name of your Active Directory group.
The regex used to validate this parameter is a string of characters consisting of uppercase and lowercase alphanumeric characters with no spaces. You can also include underscores or any of the following characters: =,.@:/-

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedAccess.HomeDirectory
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectory.
The landing directory (folder) for a user when they log in to the server using the client.
A HomeDirectory example is /bucket_name/home/mydirectory.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedAccess.HomeDirectoryType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryType.
The type of landing directory (folder) you want your users' home directory to be when they log into the server. If you set it to PATH, the user will see the absolute Amazon S3 bucket or EFS paths as is in their file transfer protocol clients. If you set it LOGICAL, you need to provide mappings in the HomeDirectoryMappings for how you want to make Amazon S3 or EFS paths visible to your users.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedAccess.Role
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Role.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that controls your users' access to your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The policies attached to this role determine the level of access that you want to provide your users when transferring files into and out of your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The IAM role should also contain a trust relationship that allows the server to access your resources when servicing your users' transfer requests.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedExecution
member.summary: Returns properties of the execution that is specified.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedExecution.ExecutionId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionId.
A unique identifier for the execution of a workflow.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedExecution.InitialFileLocation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InitialFileLocation.
A structure that describes the Amazon S3 or EFS file location. This is the file location when the execution begins: if the file is being copied, this is the initial (as opposed to destination) file location.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedExecution.ServiceMetadata
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServiceMetadata.
A container object for the session details associated with a workflow.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedExecution.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
The status is one of the execution. Can be in progress, completed, exception encountered, or handling the exception.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer
member.summary: Returns properties of a file transfer protocol-enabled server that was specified.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer.Arn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Arn.
Specifies the unique Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for a server to be listed.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer.Domain
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Domain.
Specifies the domain of the storage system that is used for file transfers.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer.EndpointType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EndpointType.
Specifies the type of VPC endpoint that your server is connected to. If your server is connected to a VPC endpoint, your server isn't accessible over the public internet.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer.IdentityProviderType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IdentityProviderType.
Specifies the mode of authentication for a server. The default value is SERVICE_MANAGED, which allows you to store and access user credentials within the Amazon Web Services Transfer Family service.
Use AWS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE to provide access to Active Directory groups in Amazon Web Services Managed Active Directory or Microsoft Active Directory in your on-premises environment or in Amazon Web Services using AD Connectors. This option also requires you to provide a Directory ID using the IdentityProviderDetails parameter.
Use the API_GATEWAY value to integrate with an identity provider of your choosing. The API_GATEWAY setting requires you to provide an API Gateway endpoint URL to call for authentication using the IdentityProviderDetails parameter.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer.LoggingRole
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LoggingRole.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon Web Services Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that allows a server to turn on Amazon CloudWatch logging for Amazon S3 or Amazon EFS events. When set, user activity can be viewed in your CloudWatch logs.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
Specifies the unique system assigned identifier for the servers that were listed.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer.State
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property State.
Specifies the condition of a server for the server that was described. A value of ONLINE indicates that the server can accept jobs and transfer files. A State value of OFFLINE means that the server cannot perform file transfer operations.
The states of STARTING and STOPPING indicate that the server is in an intermediate state, either not fully able to respond, or not fully offline. The values of START_FAILED or STOP_FAILED can indicate an error condition.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedServer.UserCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UserCount.
Specifies the number of users that are assigned to a server you specified with the ServerId.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedUser
member.summary: Returns properties of the user that you specify.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedUser.Arn
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Arn.
Provides the unique Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the user that you want to learn about.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedUser.HomeDirectory
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectory.
The landing directory (folder) for a user when they log in to the server using the client.
A HomeDirectory example is /bucket_name/home/mydirectory.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedUser.HomeDirectoryType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property HomeDirectoryType.
The type of landing directory (folder) you want your users' home directory to be when they log into the server. If you set it to PATH, the user will see the absolute Amazon S3 bucket or EFS paths as is in their file transfer protocol clients. If you set it LOGICAL, you need to provide mappings in the HomeDirectoryMappings for how you want to make Amazon S3 or EFS paths visible to your users.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListedUser.Role
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Role.
Specifies the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that controls your users' access to your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The policies attached to this role determine the level of access that you want to provide your users when transferring files into and out of your Amazon S3 bucket or EFS file system. The IAM role should also contain a trust relationship that allows the server to access your resources when servicing your users' transfer requests.
The IAM role that controls your users' access to your Amazon S3 bucket for servers with Domain=S3, or your EFS file system for servers with Domain=EFS.
The policies attached to this role determine the level of access you want to provide your users when transferring files into and out of your S3 buckets or EFS file systems.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListExecutionsRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListExecutions operation. Lists all executions for the specified workflow.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListExecutionsRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxResults.
Specifies the aximum number of executions to return.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListExecutionsRequest.NextToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NextToken.
ListExecutions returns the NextToken parameter in the output. You can then pass the NextToken parameter in a subsequent command to continue listing additional executions.
This is useful for pagination, for instance. If you have 100 executions for a workflow, you might only want to list first 10. If so, callthe API by specifing the max-results:
aws transfer list-executions --max-results 10
This returns details for the first 10 executions, as well as the pointer (NextToken) to the eleventh execution. You can now call the API again, suppling the NextToken value you received:
aws transfer list-executions --max-results 10 --next-token $somePointerReturnedFromPreviousListResult
This call returns the next 10 executions, the 11th through the 20th. You can then repeat the call until the details for all 100 executions have been returned.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListExecutionsRequest.WorkflowId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WorkflowId.
A unique identifier for the workflow.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListExecutionsResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the ListExecutions operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ListExecutionsResponse.Executions
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Executions.
Returns the details for each execution.
NextToken: returned from a call to several APIs, you can use pass it to a subsequent command to continue listing additional executions.
StartTime: timestamp indicating when the execution began.
Executions: details of the execution, including the execution ID, initial file location, and Service metadata.
Status: one of the following values: IN_PROGRESS, COMPLETED, EXCEPTION, HANDLING_EXEPTION.

member.summary:
The protocol settings that are configured for your server.
This type is only valid in the UpdateServer API.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.ProtocolDetails.PassiveIp
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PassiveIp.
Indicates passive mode, for FTP and FTPS protocols. Enter a single dotted-quad IPv4 address, such as the external IP address of a firewall, router, or load balancer. For example:
aws transfer update-server --protocol-details PassiveIp=0.0.0.0
Replace 0.0.0.0 in the example above with the actual IP address you want to use.
If you change the PassiveIp value, you must stop and then restart your Transfer server for the change to take effect. For details on using Passive IP (PASV) in a NAT environment, see Configuring your FTPS server behind a firewall or NAT with Amazon Web Services Transfer Family.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.S3InputFileLocation
member.summary:
Specifies the customer input S3 file location. If it is used inside copyStepDetails.DestinationFileLocation, it should be the S3 copy destination.
You need to provide the bucket and key. The key can represent either a path or a file. This is determined by whether or not you end the key value with the forward slash (/) character. If the final character is "/", then your file is copied to the folder, and its name does not change. If, rather, the final character is alphanumeric, your uploaded file is renamed to the path value. In this case, if a file with that name already exists, it is overwritten.
For example, if your path is shared-files/bob/, your uploaded files are copied to the shared-files/bob/, folder. If your path is shared-files/today, each uploaded file is copied to the shared-files folder and named today: each upload overwrites the previous version of the bob file.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.S3InputFileLocation.Bucket

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.StartServerRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the StartServer operation. Changes the state of a file transfer protocol-enabled server from OFFLINE to ONLINE. It has no impact on a server that is already ONLINE. An ONLINE server can accept and process file transfer jobs.
The state of STARTING indicates that the server is in an intermediate state, either not fully able to respond, or not fully online. The values of START_FAILED can indicate an error condition.
No response is returned from this call.

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.StartServerRequest.ServerId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ServerId.
A system-assigned unique identifier for a server that you start.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.StartServerResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the StartServer operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.StopServerRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the StopServer operation. Changes the state of a file transfer protocol-enabled server from ONLINE to OFFLINE. An OFFLINE server cannot accept and process file transfer jobs. Information tied to your server, such as server and user properties, are not affected by stopping your server.
Stopping the server will not reduce or impact your file transfer protocol endpoint billing; you must delete the server to stop being billed.
The state of STOPPING indicates that the server is in an intermediate state, either not fully able to respond, or not fully offline. The values of STOP_FAILED can indicate an error condition.
No response is returned from this call.

member.name: T:Amazon.Transfer.Model.TestIdentityProviderRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the TestIdentityProvider operation. If the IdentityProviderType of a file transfer protocol-enabled server is AWS_DIRECTORY_SERVICE or API_Gateway, tests whether your identity provider is set up successfully. We highly recommend that you call this operation to test your authentication method as soon as you create your server. By doing so, you can troubleshoot issues with the identity provider integration to ensure that your users can successfully use the service.
The ServerId and UserName parameters are required. The ServerProtocol, SourceIp, and UserPassword are all optional.
You cannot use TestIdentityProvider if the IdentityProviderType of your server is SERVICE_MANAGED.
If you provide any incorrect values for any parameters, the Response field is empty.
If you provide a server ID for a server that uses service-managed users, you get an error:
An error occurred (InvalidRequestException) when calling the TestIdentityProvider operation: s-server-ID not configured for external auth
If you enter a Server ID for the --server-id parameter that does not identify an actual Transfer server, you receive the following error:
An error occurred (ResourceNotFoundException) when calling the TestIdentityProvider operation: Unknown server

member.name: P:Amazon.Transfer.Model.TestIdentityProviderRequest.ServerId

A system-assigned identifier for a specific server. That server's user authentication method is tested with a user name and password.

File Transfer Protocol Secure (FTPS)
